title: All About the Northern Cardinal

slides.title: Introduction to the Northern Cardinal
slides.content: The Northern Cardinal (Cardinalis cardinalis) is a striking songbird native to North America. Famous for its bright red plumage in males and the distinctive crest on its head, it's also known as the redbird or Virginia nightingale.

slides.title: Physical Characteristics
content: Males are vibrant red with a black mask around their eyes and a prominent crest, while females are olive-brown with red tinges.
They have strong, conical beaks perfect for cracking seeds and a wingspan of about 10-12 inches.

slides.title: Song and Communication
content: Northern Cardinals have a distinctive whistle-like song that sounds like 'cheer-cheer-cheer' or 'birdie-birdie-birdie'.
Both males and females sing, which is unusual among songbirds, and they use songs to mark territory and attract mates.

slides.title: Habitat and Behavior
content: They prefer dense shrubbery, woodlands, gardens, and wetlands across eastern and central North America.
Cardinals are non-migratory and often form lifelong pair bonds, with males feeding females during courtship.

slides.title: Conservation and Symbolism
content: Northern Cardinals are common and their populations are stable, making them a species of least concern.
They are the state bird of seven U.S. states and are popular in bird feeding, often being the first birds to visit feeders in winter.
